CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;No violation of Art. 10;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;Elisabeth Steiner;Khanlar Hajiyev;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , who is living in GPE , is a practising lawyer by profession .

CARDINAL . The applicant represented a commercial manager in administrative criminal proceedings before ORG for alleged violations of ORG the FFLD ” ) . Referring to charges brought by ORG ( GPE ) concerning CARDINAL samples of turkey meat , the applicant on DATE filed observations , stating that :

“ Since the samples taken are not labelled as frozen food ( contrary to the attempt to play tricks on my client ( PERSON ) in the expert opinion underlying the criminal charge ) , they are not covered by LAW ( CARDINAL ) of the ORG . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG requested ORG to institute proceedings against the applicant , claiming that his serious and unfounded allegations had tarnished ORG reputation and were incompatible with a lawyer ’s professional duties .
CARDINAL . Subsequently , on DATE , ORG opened disciplinary proceedings against the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE he filed observations , submitting that ORG had repeatedly applied an extensive interpretation of the provisions in issue . By suggesting that the authority had attempted to play tricks on his client , he had merely sought to express his doubts as to the authority ’s legal opinion “ with a nod and a wink ” , even though there may have been sufficient grounds for instituting proceedings for abuse of authority .

CARDINAL . By decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG ( NORP ) of ORG discontinued the proceedings . It found that , while the applicant ’s allegations may have infringed the profession ’s honour and reputation , his statements disclosed only a minor degree of culpability , as they had apparently been made in the context of a heated exchange between him and the authority concerned .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG prosecutor ( PERSON ) appealed . He asserted that the expression “ attempt to play tricks on my client ” , used by the applicant , insinuated that the authority had been acting fraudulently .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , on DATE , the applicant filed observations in which he repeated his defence , namely that his remarks were not meant to be taken literally . He had resorted to innuendo , alluding to an allegedly unlawful practice on the part of ORG . He alleged in particular that the latter used its position to pursue its aims in the field of food inspection policy .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( PERSON Berufungs- und ORG ) granted the prosecutor ’s appeal . It quashed the decision of CARDINAL DATE and remitted the case to ORG .

CARDINAL . Having held an oral hearing , at which the applicant was present , ORG on DATE convicted the applicant under LAW ( ORG ) and , relying on LAW of LAW ( GPE ) , issued a written reprimand . Moreover , it ordered the applicant to pay the costs of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . ORG held that the applicant had used a defamatory and disparaging expression . Pursuant to LAW a lawyer , when defending the interests of his client , was entitled to address the perceived incorrectness of any official document in an appropriate manner . The applicant ’s statement had transgressed the limits of acceptable conduct . In the submissions at issue he had failed to indicate any facts or circumstances which would have justified the use of the expression “ attempt to play tricks on my client ” . The applicant would have been free to institute proceedings for abuse of authority ( PERSON ) , had there been grounds for such a suspicion . In conclusion , ORG found that the applicant had infringed the profession ’s honour and reputation .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal against the decision and on DATE ORG prosecutor submitted his observations in reply .

CARDINAL . Following another oral hearing , ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal on DATE . It confirmed that the applicant had transgressed the limits laid down in LAW . The impugned statement had been defamatory and had disparaged the staff of ORG . Since that statement had been made in writing , it had been well - considered . Therefore , it could not be said that the applicant had acted with a minor degree of culpability .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with ORG ) . He complained , inter alia , that there had been a violation of LAW , submitting that ORG charges against his client had been objectively wrong . By using the impugned expression , he had merely sought to emphasise his argument .

CARDINAL . By decision of DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s complaint . It found that the interference complained of had served the aim of maintaining the authority and impartiality of the judiciary and that the disciplinary authorities had duly balanced the applicant ’s rights under the LAW against the profession ’s interest in safeguarding its standards of professional duties . Hence , they had given ample reasons why there had been no violation of the applicant ’s right to freedom of expression . The decision was served on the applicant on DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW ( ORG ) regulates the professional duties incumbent on lawyers . When representing a client , a lawyer is entitled to make use of any means of defence which are not contrary to his mandate , his conscience or the law .

CARDINAL . According to section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ( GPE ) , a lawyer who acts in breach of his / her professional duties or , through his / her conduct within or outside his / her professional activity , infringes the profession ’s honour or reputation , is deemed to have committed a disciplinary offence which must be dealt with by ORG .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW , in the version applicable at the material time , provided for the following disciplinary penalties : a written reprimand , a fine of MONEY , a prohibition on practising as a lawyer for a period not exceeding one year and removal from the Bar roll .
